Docker
docker run <image> <command> Create a writeable container layer over the specified image, and then starts it using the specified command.
--rm Automatically remove the container when it exits.
-t
--tty Allocate a pseudo-TTY.
-i
--interactive Keep STDIN open even if not attached.
-d
--detached Run container in background and print container ID.
--restart=always Always restart the container regardless of the exit status.
--name <name> Assign a name to the container.
-p 80:5000
--publish 80:5000 Map port 80 of the host to port 5000 of the container.
-e <myvar>=<value>
-env <myvar>=<value> Set an environment variable in the container.
-e <myvar>
-env <myvar> Set an environment variable with its value which is already defined in the local environment in the container.
--env-file <file> Read in a file of environment variables.
--link <name or id>:alias Create a link between the newly started container and a running one.
It is possible to use --link <name or id>, in which case the alias will be the name of the other container.
This will add an entry in the /etc/hosts of the started container with an IP address for the alias, name, and id of the existing linked container.
--volume <hostdirectory>:<containerdirectory>
-v <hostdirectory>:<containerdirectory> Mount <hostdirectory> as <imagedirectory> in the container. If <hostdirectory> does not exist, it will be created.
docker load Load an image or repository from a tar archive (optionally compressed with gzip, bzip2, or xz) from stdin.
docker load < busybox.tar.gz
-i
--input Read from a file instead of stdin.
docker load --input busybox.tar.gz
docker start <container>
docker container start <container> Start a stopped container
(it is possible to have several container names, e.g. docker start <container1> <container2> <container3>).
-i
--interactive Attach container’s STDIN.
-a
--attach Attach STDOUT/STDERR and forward signals.
docker stop <container>
docker container stop <container> Stop the container <container> (it is possible to have several container names docker stop <container1> <container2> <container3>).
The main process inside the container will receive SIGTERM, and after a grace period (10 seconds by default), SIGKILL.
-t <n>
--time <n> Seconds to wait for stop before sending SIGKILL.
docker stop $(docker ps -q) Stop all containers.
docker kill <container>
docker container kill <container> Send a SIGKILL signal to the main process in the container.
-s <signal>
--signal <signal> Define the signal to send (e.g. docker kill --signal=SIGHUP mycontainer).
docker restart <container>
docker container restart <container> Restart the container.
docker rm <container>
docker container rm <container> Remove the container <container>.
docker exec <container> <command>
docker container exec <container> <command> Execute a command in a container (e.g. docker exec mycontainer cat /etc/hosts.
docker exec -i <container> sh
docker exec --interactive <container> sh Create an interactive shell in a container (add the -t flag, otherwise there is no prompt).
docker exec -t
docker exec --tty Allocate a pseudo-TTY.
docker ps
docker container ls
docker container list
docker container ps List the running containers.
-a
--all List all containers (running or not).
-q
--quiet Only display container IDs.
-s
--size Display total file sizes.
docker inspect <container> Return low-level information about a container.
docker volume ls List all Docker volumes.
docker volume create <volume> Create volume <volume>.
docker volume rm <volume> Delete volume <volume>.
docker volume prune Remove all unused local volumes (i.e volumes which are not referenced by any containers).
docker volume inspect <volume> Return information about volume <volume>.
docker network ls List the networks.
docker network create <network> Create network <network>.
docker network rm <network> Delete network <network>.
docker network prune Remove all unused local network (i.e network which are not referenced by any containers).
docker network inspect <network> Return information about network <network>.
docker logs <container> Display the logs of a container.
-f
--follow Keep following the logs.
-t
--timestamps Show timestamps.
--tail 200
-n 200 Display the 200 last lines.
--since 10m Display the logs of the last 10 minutes (it is also possible to give a date 2013-01-02T13:23:37Z).
--until 60m Display the logs older than 60 minutes (it is also possible to give a date).
--details Display more details.
Unreferenced images are images not referenced by any container.
Dangling images are layers that have no relationship to any tagged images.
docker images
docker image ls List the top level images.
-a
--all List all images (top level and intermediate).
-f dangling=true List the dangling images.
docker image rm <image1> <image2> … Remove some images.
docker system prune Remove all unused containers, networks, and images (both dangling and unreferenced).
-a
--all Remove all unused images not just dangling ones.
--volumes Also prune volumes.
-f
--force Do not prompt for confirmation.
docker cp foobar.txt quux:/opt/mydir Copy the local file foobar.txt in the directory /opt/mydir of container quux.
docker login -u <login> -p <password> <server>
docker login --username <login> --password <password> <server> Log in to a Docker registry.
docker logout <server> Log out from a Docker registry.
Notes
To add something in an Alpine container
docker exec -it –-user=root mycontainer /bin/sh
apk add curl rm -f /var/cache/apl/*
On Windows and Mac, use host.docker.internal instead of localhost to refer to the host from inside a container (some information herehttps://stackoverflow.com/questions/24319662/from-inside-of-a-docker-container-how-do-i-connect-to-the-localhost-of-the-mach
enHTML).

Docker compose
docker-compose -f conf.yaml Use the configuration file conf.yaml
docker-compose -f conf1.yaml -f conf2.yaml Use the configuration file which is the concatenation of conf1.yaml and conf2.yaml.
docker-compose up Create and start containers.
-d
--detach Detached mode: Run containers in the background.
docker-compose start Starts existing containers for a service.
docker-compose stop Stops running containers without removing them. They can be started again with docker compose start.
docker-compose down Stop and remove containers and networks.
docker-compose ps List containers.
--service Display services.
docker-compose logs <service> View output from containers. It is possible to specify no or several services.
-f
--follow Keep following the logs.
--tail 200
-n 200 Display the 200 last lines.
Docker compose will look for an .env file to define environment variables in the containers.
Analyse a Docker image with Trivy:
docker run -v /tmp/trivy/Caches:/root/.cache/ aquasec/trivy:0.51.2 image squashtest/squash-tm:6.1.0 > log_6.1.0.txt
